info.game_comments:
2000-B College Championship final game 1. 
From the University of Washington in Seattle.

(1, 1).clue: Michelangelo made "David", seen here, from this rock

(2, 1).clue: This Jell-O pudding pitchman said the darnedest things to kids at Xavier University's commencement

(3, 1).clue: His hunting rifle accessory made him "Telescope Teddy"

(4, 1).clue: Most of this "Color Purple" author's first volume of poetry, "Once", was written in one week in 1964

(5, 1).clue: Term for a player who isn't recruited, but just "ambles" onto the field to try out

(2, 2).clue: Graduates of Middlebury College in Vermont listened to this former president -- of Poland

(4, 2).clue: "Howl", his first book of poetry, was published by City Lights, a bookstore owned by poet Lawrence Ferlinghetti

(5, 2).clue: Mississippi State is represented by this persistent creature seen here

(6, 2).clue: It's an old warning said on parting about not accepting false five-cent pieces

(1, 3).clue: A basic copper aluminum phosphate, it's the type of stone used here in an ancient Aztec ornament

(2, 3).clue: This author took "The Firm" stance of telling Arkansas State grads to "leave the country"

(3, 3).clue: The "Father of the Declaration of Independence"

(4, 3).clue: In "Endymion" he wrote, "A thing of beauty is a joy forever"

(5, 3).clue: The university of this state was the fitting 1999-2000 champion of the Big Sky Conference

(6, 3).clue: Term for the money used to "germinate" a new business, like maybe a flower shop

(1, 4).clue: Stalactites & stalagmites are formed primarily in caves of this "stone"

(2, 4).clue: Take a memo:Stanford got a secretary to speak -- this Secretary-General

(3, 4).clue: "The Hero of Fort Donelson" as well as "The Hero of Appomattox"

(4, 4).clue: In 1945 this South American country's Gabriela Mistral won the Nobel Prize for Literature

(5, 4).clue: This school's 1999 win over its archrival was overshadowed by the fatal collapse of a bonfire tower

(6, 4).clue: It was an old translation of the Bible that turned "money obtained dishonestly" into "filthy" this

(1, 5).clue: It's the earthy term for crystal lime nodules like the one seen here

(2, 5).clue: In May 2000 Princeton got a queen, this Mideastern one, who's a Princeton alumna

(4, 5).clue: A poem by Poe purports to be the confession of this lame Asiatic conqueror, also a Christopher Marlowe subject

(5, 5).clue: The Outland Trophy goes to the nation's outstanding interior one of these -- no, not decorator

(6, 5).clue: To destroy someone's financial condition little by little is to do this to them "to death"

(1, 1).clue: In 1999 he hit the road with his E Street Band in their first major tour in over a decade

(2, 1).clue: Both Continental Congresses met in this city; the first convened on September 5, 1774, the second on May 10, 1775

(3, 1).clue: This comedian & sitcom star has written about "Couplehood"

(4, 1).clue: This U.S. university performs its Hasty Pudding theatricals in Bermuda during "College Weeks" in March & April

(5, 1).clue: Every 12 years, followers of Jainism travel to Mysore in this country to bathe a statue of Gomateshwara

(1, 2).clue: She's the distinctive-voiced singer whose recent hits include "I Try" & "Do Something"

(2, 2).clue: More than 1000 British soldiers were killed or wounded in this June 17, 1775 battle in Massachusetts

(3, 2).clue: As this geeky bow-tie-clad character, Paul Reubens played a sold-out show at Carnegie Hall

(4, 2).clue: The resort of Puerto Vallarta in this country lies on Banderas Bay, presumably not named for Antonio

(5, 2).clue: This Jewish holy day follows Rosh Hashanah by 10 days

(6, 2).clue: Perhaps a much-sought northwest one, it's a corridor or pathway enclosed on both sides

(1, 3).clue: The secret's out -- this Rob Thomas group grew out of another band called Tabitha's Secret

(2, 3).clue: To aid them in the war, the British hired about 30,000 of these German soldiers, so named for their home principality

(3, 3).clue: After leaving "SNL", he joined the original cast of "Just Shoot Me"

(4, 3).clue: A museum in Tahiti is devoted to this French artist's works & his life in Polynesia

(5, 3).clue: The basis of this religion's caste system can be found in the Manu Smriti, or Code of Manu

(6, 3).clue: It means "unresisting", but it often precedes "resistance"

(1, 4).clue: (Hi, I'm Nile Rodgers)  2 of the hit albums I produced during the '80s were "Like A Virgin" by Madonna & "Let's Dance" by this singer

(2, 4).clue: Guerrilla leader Francis Marion earned this nickname for his daring raids from the South Carolina marshes

(3, 4).clue: I don't want to get off on a rant, but this comic was great when he started on "MNF" in July 2000

(4, 4).clue: A haunted castle full of mummies is a new attraction at the West Edmonton Mall in this Canadian province

(5, 4).clue: Followers of this Japanese religion believe that the sun goddess was the ancestor of the Imperial Family

(6, 4).clue: This word borrowed from French means "outmoded"

(1, 5).clue: They're the rockers in the song heard here("Can you take me higher...")

(3, 5).clue: His 1997 comedy special was called "Bring The Pain!"

(5, 5).clue: This religious leader was born around 563 B.C. in what is now Nepal
